study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy of complementary therapies, including massage, for pain management in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that massage, among other complementary therapies, has some efficacy in affecting pain and anxiety in older populations and warrants further investigation.
population_specificity: Older adults, particularly those in residential care settings or with chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of massage as a conservative, nonsurgical, nonpharmacologic treatment for alleviating pain and improving function in patients with osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that massage, along with other nonpharmacologic treatments like exercise, can alleviate pain and improve function in osteoarthritis patients, though specific details on massage's efficacy are not provided.
population_specificity: Older adults (age > 65 years) with osteoarthritis, particularly affecting the hip and knee.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of uterine massage, along with other interventions, in reducing post-partum hemorrhage risk during the third stage of labor.
results_summary: Uterine massage was associated with an increased risk of hemorrhage in both clinical regimens studied, suggesting it may not be beneficial in this context. The study found no evidence supporting its efficacy when combined with other interventions.
population_specificity: Post-partum women in hospital-based births across four countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of spinal manipulative therapy (including minimal massage) with other standard treatments for acute or chronic low-back pain.
results_summary: Spinal manipulative therapy (including minimal massage) was found to be superior only to sham therapy or therapies judged ineffective or harmful, but it showed no significant advantage over other standard treatments like general practitioner care, analgesics, physical therapy, exercises, or back school.
population_specificity: Patients with acute or chronic low-back pain.
study_duration: At least one day of follow-up (specific intervention duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of lumbar tender point deep tissue massage combined with lumbar traction versus lumbar traction alone on chronic non-specific low back pain, using pressure pain threshold, muscle hardness, and pain intensity as measures.
results_summary: The treatment group (massage + traction) showed significantly greater improvements in pressure pain threshold, reduced muscle hardness, and lower pain intensity compared to the control group (traction alone), with statistically significant differences (P < 0.05).
population_specificity: 64 patients with chronic non-specific low back pain (60 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether back massage improves sleep quality in postpartum women.
results_summary: The study found that a 5-day back massage intervention significantly improved sleep quality in postpartum women, as measured by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), with statistically significant reductions in PSQI scores compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Postpartum women reporting poor sleep quality in Northern Taiwan.
effective_dosage: Single 20-minute back massage session each evening for 5 consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of cervical mobilization techniques versus massage therapy in managing cervicogenic headache (CGH).
results_summary: Massage therapy showed significant improvement in headache pain intensity, frequency, duration, and neck mobility, but cervical mobilization techniques were more effective in most measured variables except the functional Neck Disability Index (NDI).
population_specificity: 36 subjects with cervicogenic headache (CGH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a self-directed program including massage techniques for improving mental health and interpersonal connectedness in National Guard personnel and their partners post-deployment.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in PTSD, depression, self-compassion, and stress reduction, with veterans reporting reduced physical pain, tension, irritability, anxiety, and depression after massage. Longitudinal analysis suggested declining baseline levels of tension and irritability.
population_specificity: National Guard personnel and their significant relationship partners returning from Iraq or Afghanistan.
effective_dosage: Instruction in simple massage techniques (DVD), frequency not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the scientific evidence on the effects of manual therapy techniques, including massage, on children with respiratory diseases.
results_summary: Of the 8 studies reviewed, 6 found benefits from manual therapy, including improvements in spirometric parameters, immunologic tests, anxiety levels, and salivary cortisol. Only 2 studies did not identify positive results.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with respiratory diseases, including asthma, cystic fibrosis, bronchiolitis, and recurrent respiratory infections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of physiotherapy (including abdominal massage) combined with laxatives versus laxatives alone in treating chronic functional constipation in children.
results_summary: The physiotherapy group (including abdominal massage) showed a higher frequency of bowel movements after 6 weeks compared to the medication-only group, but there was no difference in fecal incontinence frequency between the groups.
population_specificity: Children aged 4-18 years with functional constipation according to Rome III criteria.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions of 40 minutes each, twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether massage therapy (MT) improves autonomic nervous system (ANS) function and stress response in preterm infants, as measured by heart rate variability (HRV).
results_summary: Male infants receiving MT showed improved ANS function during caregiving and sleep, while control males exhibited decreased HRV. No significant differences were observed in female infants between MT and control groups.
population_specificity: Medically stable preterm infants (21 participants, 8 males and 13 females) with a mean post-menstrual age of ~31 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and effects of providing therapeutic massage at home for patients with metastatic cancer, comparing massage therapy to no-touch intervention and usual care.
results_summary: The study found that therapeutic massage improved quality of life after 1 week, though the effect was not sustained at 1 month. Trends toward improvement in pain and sleep were observed in the massage group but not in control groups, with no serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic cancer.
effective_dosage: Mean of 2.8 massage therapy sessions per patient.
study_duration: 1-week follow-up, with some outcomes assessed at 1 month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of massage on affect, relaxation, and experimental pain induced by electrical stimulation.
results_summary: The study found that massage conditions (with or without guided imagery) reduced pain unpleasantness, lowered unpleasant affect, maintained pleasant affect, and increased relaxation compared to no treatment, though no differences were observed in pain intensity, threshold, or tolerance.
population_specificity: 96 healthy women (mean age 20.13 ± 5.93 years; 84.4% White).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate the physiological effects and various massage techniques for treating myofascial pain, particularly in the masseter and temporal muscles, and to present a treatment protocol.
results_summary: The study found that massage therapy is clinically useful for myofascial pain, improving both subjective and objective health status, and is easy to follow. The authors highlighted different massage techniques and their benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with myofascial pain in the head region, specifically affecting the stomatognathic system.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the incidence and predictors of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) use, including massage therapy, among thyroid cancer patients.
results_summary: Massage therapy was one of the top five CAM modalities used by thyroid cancer patients, primarily for symptom treatment rather than direct cancer treatment. Few patients reported negative effects from CAM use, though physician awareness of CAM use was low.
population_specificity: Thyroid cancer patients, primarily over age 40, white, female, and college-educated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of hand and foot massage on post-cesarean section pain and its potential to reduce analgesic requests.
results_summary: The study found that hand and foot massage significantly reduced post-cesarean pain intensity (p < .001) and decreased requests for analgesics (p < .001), suggesting it as an effective complementary method for pain management.
population_specificity: 80 pregnant women who underwent elective cesarean section at Mustafa Khomeini Hospital, Elam, Iran.
effective_dosage: 5 minutes of foot and hand massage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immediate and short-term effectiveness of Long's manipulation (LM) versus traditional Chinese massage (TCM) in treating chronic neck pain.
results_summary: LM showed significantly greater improvements in pain intensity, neck disability, and patient satisfaction compared to TCM, with effects lasting up to 3 months. No significant differences were found in craniovertebral angle and most cervical range of motion measures, except for flexion at 3-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic mechanical neck pain.
effective_dosage: 8 treatment sessions (one session every three days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and effectiveness of massage therapy in reducing perioperative pain and anxiety in low-income, underserved cancer patients undergoing port insertion.
results_summary: Massage therapy significantly reduced anxiety compared to structured attention, with a greater reduction in anxiety scores (-10.27 vs -5.21, P = .0037). Both interventions were beneficial for alleviating preoperative anxiety, but massage showed superior efficacy.
population_specificity: Low-income, urban cancer patients (67% racial/ethnic minorities, majority female, unemployed, with household incomes <$30,000 and public health insurance) undergoing surgical port placement.
effective_dosage: 20-minute massage sessions immediately pre- and postsurgery.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of electrophysical modality treatments, including ultrasound plus friction massage, for lateral epicondylitis (LE).
results_summary: Moderate evidence supports the effectiveness of ultrasound plus friction massage versus laser therapy on short-term follow-up for LE. However, evidence for other modalities was limited or conflicting.
population_specificity: Patients with lateral epicondylitis (LE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether massage could improve weight gain, reduce hospital stay, and promote neurobehavioral development in preterm infants.
results_summary: Massage intervention significantly improved daily weight gain by 5.32 g and reduced hospital stay by 4.41 days, but no significant effects were observed on neurobehavioral development scores.
population_specificity: Clinically stable preterm infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the prevalence of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) use, including massage therapy, among active duty military personnel versus civilians.
results_summary: Approximately 14.1% of military respondents reported using massage therapy, indicating it was one of the most commonly used CAM therapies. Military personnel used stress-reduction CAM therapies, including massage, at 2.5-7 times the rate of civilians.
population_specificity: Active duty military personnel, stratified by gender, service, region, and pay grade.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of standardized electric acupuncture and massage compared to rehabilitation therapy for shoulder-hand syndrome in hemiplegia patients.
results_summary: The acupuncture-massage group showed significant improvements in pain reduction, functional movement of the upper limb, and progression of shoulder-hand syndrome compared to the rehabilitation group, with results sustained at a 12-week follow-up.
population_specificity: Hemiplegia patients with stage I shoulder-hand syndrome (n=120).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of massage as a complementary and alternative therapy for treating constipation in older adults.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that massage is relatively easy to use and likely to cause few adverse reactions, but methodological problems in studies limit definitive conclusions about its efficacy.
population_specificity: Older adults with constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of massage on oxytocin (OT) and other physiologic factors (ACTH, NO, BE) and explore its role in social bonding.
results_summary: Massage increased oxytocin levels and reduced ACTH, NO, and BE, with significant differences between the massage and control groups. These findings suggest massage may enhance social bonding and reduce stress-related biomarkers.
population_specificity: 95 participants from UCLA (65 in the massage group, 30 in the control group), mixed gender.
effective_dosage: 15 minutes of moderate-pressure massage of the upper back.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a randomized clinical trial comparing myofascial physical therapy and global therapeutic massage for treating urological chronic pelvic pain syndromes.
results_summary: The study found that myofascial physical therapy had a significantly higher response rate (57%) compared to global therapeutic massage (21%). Therapist adherence to protocols was excellent, and 94% of participants completed the study.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome or interstitial cystitis/painful bladder syndrome (23 men and 24 women).
effective_dosage: Up to 10 weekly treatments of 1 hour each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of breastfeeding or supplemental breast milk in reducing procedural pain in neonates, with a secondary focus on comparing these methods to other interventions like massage.
results_summary: Breastfeeding was found to significantly reduce pain markers (e.g., heart rate, crying time) compared to positioning, placebo, or no intervention, but supplemental breast milk showed variable results and was less effective than sucrose. Massage was mentioned as a comparator, with breast milk being significantly better than massage in reducing pain scores.
population_specificity: Neonates undergoing painful procedures (heel lance or venepuncture).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combining anesthetic blockage of the auriculotemporal nerve with physical therapy (massage and muscular stretching exercises) for reducing pain in patients with temporomandibular joint disorders.
results_summary: The study found that combining anesthetic blockage with physical therapy significantly reduced pain (p=0.027) compared to anesthetic blockage alone, though no significant differences were observed for other variables like mouth opening or jaw protrusion.
population_specificity: Twenty patients diagnosed with disc displacement with/without reduction and arthralgia (RDC/TMD Axis I Group IIa, IIb, and IIIa).
effective_dosage: Not specified for massage; anesthetic blockage involved 1 ml of bupivacaine 0.5% weekly for 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to propose an algorithm for treating postabortion hemorrhage, including massage as part of medical therapy.
results_summary: The abstract mentions massage as part of a stepwise approach to treating postabortion hemorrhage, but no specific results regarding its effectiveness are provided. The overall focus is on identifying high-risk patients and developing a structured treatment plan.
population_specificity: Women experiencing postabortion hemorrhage, particularly those at high risk (e.g., with uterine scar or placenta previa).

study_goal: To compare the clinical effects, treatment times, and rheoencephalogram changes between innovative Tuina manipulations and routine Tuina manipulations in vertebral artery type cervical spondylosis patients.
results_summary: The innovative Tuina manipulations showed a 100% response rate and required fewer treatments (7 +/- 4) compared to the control group (88.71% response rate, 15 +/- 7 treatments). Symptoms improved more in the test group, but cerebral blood flow changes were similar between groups.
population_specificity: 126 vertebral artery type cervical spondylosis patients.
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatment frequency based on recovery).
study_duration: Until recovery (test group: 7 +/- 4 treatments; control group: 15 +/- 7 treatments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of deep and superficial massage, stretching, and active/passive recovery on blood lactate concentration and other physiological parameters after fatiguing exercise.
results_summary: Massage (deep and superficial) and stretching did not significantly alter blood lactate kinetics compared to passive recovery, while active recovery showed lower lactate levels and higher metabolic/cardiorespiratory parameters.
population_specificity: Nine healthy participants (age 23 ± 1 years, body mass 74 ± 4 kg).
study_duration: 10 minutes per session, followed by 1-hour recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various therapeutic interventions, including massage therapy, for treating hemiplegic shoulder pain in individuals more than 6 months post-stroke.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for massage therapy, only noting that it was one of the interventions studied among others like corticosteroid injections and electrical stimulation.
population_specificity: Adults with hemiplegic shoulder pain who had experienced a stroke at least 6 months prior.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the frequency of massage use among physiotherapists in rehabilitating patients after a distal radial fracture and examine whether patient or therapist characteristics influenced intervention frequency.
results_summary: Massage was used in 60 out of 160 consultations, making it one of the common interventions, though less frequent than exercise and advice. The study did not specifically evaluate massage's efficacy or safety but noted its routine use in rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from distal radial fractures treated in outpatient physiotherapy departments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether abdominal massage or pelvic rotation could trigger small bowel volvulus in very premature newborns with normal intra-abdominal anatomy.
results_summary: The study found that intensive abdominal massage or pelvic rotation in very premature newborns was associated with small bowel volvulus, leading the authors to term it a "manufactured" volvulus and discontinue the practice.
population_specificity: Very premature newborns (27-31 weeks gestational age, birth weight 800-1,000 g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the use and interest in complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) therapies, including massage, among outpatients with cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: The study found that 19.2% of patients reported using massage as a CAM therapy, but it did not specifically evaluate massage's effects on cardiovascular outcomes. The top treatments for cardiac symptoms were relaxation techniques, stress management, meditation, and guided imagery.
population_specificity: Outpatients with cardiovascular disease (mean age 63.5 years, 98.1% white) undergoing cardiology evaluation at a Midwestern tertiary care center.

study_goal: To review the efficacy of massage as a non-pharmacological approach for managing agitated behaviors in older people with dementia and provide recommendations for future research.
results_summary: Only one study of adequate methodological quality was found, which showed that massage significantly reduced agitation levels in cognitively impaired residents in long-term care facilities. The review highlights a severe lack of high-quality research on this topic but suggests potential benefits of massage.
population_specificity: Older people with dementia, specifically 52 cognitively impaired residents in long-term care facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the association between carotid sinus massage and symptoms like syncope, as well as its clinical implications in asymptomatic older individuals.
results_summary: The study found evidence linking carotid sinus massage to syncope in hypersensitive individuals but noted uncertainty about its significance in asymptomatic older persons. Some patients improved with treatments like permanent pacing, but randomized controlled trial data are lacking.
population_specificity: Older patients, both symptomatic (e.g., syncope) and asymptomatic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether massage therapy enhances the immune system of stable preterm infants, specifically by increasing natural killer (NK) cell numbers and cytotoxicity.
results_summary: Massage therapy was associated with higher NK cytotoxicity and greater daily weight gain in preterm infants, though absolute NK cell numbers and other immunologic parameters did not differ significantly between groups. No differences were observed in infection rates or length of hospital stay.
population_specificity: Stable premature infants in the NICU.
study_duration: Until hospital discharge, for a maximum of 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and impact of aromatherapy massage on individuals with Idiopathic Environmental Intolerance (IEI).
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of aromatherapy massage on IEI condition, but short-term mood enhancement was observed after each session.
population_specificity: Sixteen IEI patients attending a clinic in Sapporo city.
effective_dosage: Four one-hour aromatherapy massage sessions every two weeks.
study_duration: The active period involved sessions over eight weeks (four sessions total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM), specifically massage therapy, on reducing hopelessness in ovarian cancer patients.
results_summary: Massage therapy significantly reduced hopelessness scores (-1.07, P = .02), with employed patients being twice as likely to use massage. Patients with strong faith and good quality of life also showed reduced hopelessness.
population_specificity: Ovarian cancer patients (N = 219) undergoing treatment at a comprehensive cancer center in the United States, including newly diagnosed, long-term survivors, and recurrent cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether massage therapy reduces symptoms of depression in HIV-positive individuals with major depressive disorder.
results_summary: Massage significantly reduced depression severity by week 4, with effects continuing through weeks 6 and 8 compared to no intervention or touch. The results suggest massage therapy can alleviate depressive symptoms in this population.
population_specificity: HIV-seropositive individuals (aged ≥16) with major depressive disorder, medically stable and on stable neuropsychiatric/antiretroviral regimens.
effective_dosage: 1-hour sessions twice per week (Swedish massage or touch).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a parental intervention involving infant massage could reduce stress levels in parents of very preterm infants hospitalized in a NICU, with a focus on differences between mothers and fathers.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced stress related to infants' appearance/behavior and parental role alteration in mothers, but not in fathers. Mothers generally reported higher stress levels compared to fathers.
population_specificity: Parents of infants born ≤ 32 weeks gestational age (GA) in a NICU.
study_duration: From the first week of admission until the infant's discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy and feasibility of massage/body-work as part of an integrated treatment plan for survivors of torture and refugee trauma.
results_summary: Preliminary research suggests that massage may be effective as part of an integrated treatment plan for survivors of torture and refugee trauma, though further research is warranted. The abstract does not provide specific details on the magnitude or consistency of effects.
population_specificity: Survivors of torture and refugee trauma

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a multimodal exercise intervention, including massage, could reduce cancer-related fatigue (CRF) in patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced CRF, with a Fatigue score reduction of 3.04 (effect size 0.44), but did not significantly affect general quality of life or individual wellbeing scores. Massage was part of the multimodal approach, but its specific effects were not isolated.
population_specificity: 213 cancer patients with various diagnoses undergoing chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 9 hours weekly (part of a multimodal intervention including massage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether reflexology foot massage has a specific hemodynamic effect on cardiovascular parameters and to assess the methodological quality of existing RCTs on reflexology.
results_summary: The review found some evidence that reflexology affects selected cardiovascular parameters, but methodological flaws, such as lack of control for nonspecific massage effects, limit the ability to confirm a specific hemodynamic effect. Further research with better designs is needed to validate reflexology's therapeutic claims.
population_specificity: Adult subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of massage on weight gain and body fat deposition in preterm infants.
results_summary: Massage did not promote greater weight gain but limited body fat deposition in male preterm infants and decreased circulating adiponectin over time in males, suggesting sex-specific effects on growth quality.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (29-32 weeks gestational age).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 4-week massage intervention could reduce distress and enhance antibody responses to hepatitis B vaccination in medical students facing academic exams.
results_summary: The study found that massage did not reduce emotional distress during exams and was associated with lower antibody responses to hepatitis B vaccination at both measured time points.
population_specificity: 70 medical student volunteers (36 women, 34 men) preparing for academic examinations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence and management of pain in cancer patients, including the role of non-interventional methods like massage therapy.
results_summary: The study noted that massage therapy became increasingly popular among cancer patients, but specific efficacy data were not detailed. Non-drug methods, including massage, were used by 25.4% of patients.
population_specificity: Cancer patients attending outpatient departments at the National Cancer Centre in Singapore.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether reflexology massage to specific areas of the feet (thought to correspond to the heart) affects cardiovascular parameters compared to control areas.
results_summary: The study found a modest but statistically significant decrease in cardiac index during left foot reflexology treatment, with a small effect size. No significant changes were noted in other cardiovascular parameters or anxiety levels.
population_specificity: 16 reflexology-naive healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and test a standardized Swedish massage protocol for osteoarthritis of the knee, balancing reproducibility with individualized therapy.
results_summary: The study successfully created a manualized Swedish massage protocol, which was implemented in two randomized clinical trials. Significant treatment effects were demonstrated in the dose-finding study, indicating efficacy for osteoarthritis of the knee.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis of the knee

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update evidence-based clinical practice guidelines on the effectiveness of massage therapy for adults with acute, sub-acute, and chronic low back pain compared to control or other treatments.
results_summary: The study found that massage therapy is effective for pain relief and improving functional status, particularly for sub-acute and chronic low back pain, with short-term benefits. Combining massage with therapeutic exercise and education enhanced its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Adults (>18 years) suffering from acute, sub-acute, and chronic low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combined procedure of massage and electrotherapy with interferential current was more effective than superficial massage in improving disability, pain, and quality of life in individuals with chronic non-specific low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that interferential current electro-massage significantly improved disability, pain, and quality of life compared to superficial massage, with statistically significant improvements in visual analogue scale, Oswestry Disability Index, Roland Morris Disability Questionnaire, and quality of life scores.
population_specificity: Sixty-two individuals with chronic non-specific low back pain of mechanical aetiology.
effective_dosage: 20 sessions (twice a week) of massage with interferential current.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether a 3-minute slow-stroke back massage (SSBM) could improve nighttime sleep in older adults with dementia and sleep disturbances in a nursing home setting.
results_summary: The SSBM group showed a 36-minute increase in nighttime sleep compared to the control group, but statistical analysis did not reveal significant differences between the groups. The study suggests SSBM may be a promising intervention but requires further testing for definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Older adults (aged 65+) with dementia and sleep disturbances in a nursing home.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of massage in reducing occupational low back pain and its impact on work and life activities for nursing staff.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain reduction (p=0.000 and p=0.004) and disability scores (p=0.02), indicating massage was effective in alleviating low back pain and improving functional outcomes.
population_specificity: 18 nursing team employees with occupational low back pain.
effective_dosage: Seven to eight massage sessions after work periods.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied over multiple sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of olive oil and sunflower seed oil on skin biophysical properties, particularly regarding stratum corneum integrity, hydration, and erythema.
results_summary: Olive oil application reduced stratum corneum integrity and caused mild erythema, while sunflower seed oil preserved skin integrity, improved hydration, and did not cause erythema. The study concluded that olive oil may damage the skin barrier and exacerbate atopic dermatitis, whereas sunflower seed oil was beneficial.
population_specificity: Adult volunteers with and without a history of atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: Six drops applied twice daily (olive oil in both cohorts, sunflower seed oil in the second cohort).
study_duration: 5 weeks for the first cohort (olive oil only), 4 weeks for the second cohort (both oils).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the pathophysiology of postoperative edema following peripheral bypass surgery and evaluate treatment strategies, including lymph massage, to reduce edema.
results_summary: The study found that lymph massage, along with external compression, is a successful treatment strategy for reducing postoperative edema. The pathophysiology involves reperfusion-associated inflammation and lymphatic disruptions, though it is not fully understood.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent peripheral bypass surgery and experienced substantial lower-limb edema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal dosing (frequency and duration) of massage therapy for treating chronic neck pain.
results_summary: The study compared various dosing combinations (2-3 sessions per week of 30 or 60 minutes) over 4 weeks, with some participants receiving additional 6 weekly sessions. Outcomes were assessed at multiple time points up to 39 weeks, but specific efficacy results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 228 adults with chronic non-specific neck pain recruited from primary care clinics in Seattle.
effective_dosage: 2 or 3 sessions per week of 30 minutes, or 1, 2, or 3 sessions per week of 60 minutes.
study_duration: Primary treatment period of 4 weeks, with some participants receiving an additional 6 weeks of treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of massage on pain, function, patient satisfaction, and other outcomes in adults with mechanical neck disorders (MND) compared to other treatments.
results_summary: The study found very low to low evidence that certain massage techniques may improve function and tenderness, and may be more beneficial than education for short-term pain relief. However, the overall quality of evidence was poor, and no firm conclusions could be drawn.
population_specificity: Adults with mechanical neck disorders (MND).
study_duration: Majority assessed outcomes immediately post-treatment; long-term effects were not adequately studied.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic yield of the implantable loop recorder (ILR) in patients with unexplained syncope, including the role of carotid sinus massage as a predictor of arrhythmia.
results_summary: The ILR identified an arrhythmic mechanism in 20 patients (17 bradyarrhythmias, 3 tachyarrhythmias) and excluded arrhythmias in 12. Negative carotid sinus massage results were a negative predictor of arrhythmia.
population_specificity: 75 patients (44 males, mean age 64 ± 20 years) with unexplained syncope.
study_duration: Follow-up of 11.9 ± 9.5 months after ILR implantation.

study_goal: To determine if massage significantly reduces anxiety, pain, and muscular tension and enhances relaxation compared to rest time after cardiac surgery, while assessing feasibility, physiological effects, and patient satisfaction.
results_summary: Massage therapy significantly reduced pain, anxiety, and muscular tension while improving relaxation and satisfaction compared to rest time, with no significant differences in heart rate, respiratory rate, or blood pressure. The effects were consistent across multiple post-surgery days.
population_specificity: Elective cardiac surgery patients
study_duration: Administered at 2 points after surgery (days 3 or 4 and days 5 or 6)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether giving a massage impacted the mental state of the massage therapist, specifically focusing on anxiety, depression, and stress.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction in subjective anxiety (DASS Anxiety Subscale, p=0.014) for the massage group compared to the control group, but no significant differences in total DASS score, depressive symptoms, or stress-related symptoms. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Healthy female and male final-term massage students aged 18-65 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to objectively evaluate whether local effleurage massage enhances the efficacy of moisturizer application on skin barrier properties.
results_summary: The study found that massage after moisturizer application did not enhance moisturizer efficacy, with both massage and no-massage protocols showing comparable improvements in skin hydration, barrier permeability, and elasticity over a 2-week treatment period, which persisted during a 1-week regression phase.
population_specificity: 13 female subjects
effective_dosage: Twice-daily moisturizer application followed by 1-minute superficial massage (for one forearm)
study_duration: 2-week treatment phase followed by 1-week regression period

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of massage and cold-water immersion on perceptual and performance recovery markers in basketball players after competitive matches.
results_summary: Massage reduced perception of fatigue overall and in the legs immediately after application, similar to cold-water immersion. However, cold-water immersion was more effective than massage in improving jump performance, while neither intervention affected repeated-sprint ability.
population_specificity: 16 basketball players (8 men, 8 women) aged 22-23 years.
study_duration: Interventions applied immediately post-match, with assessments 24 hours later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of massage and heat on insulin absorption and postprandial glucose excursions in diabetes therapy.
results_summary: Massage and heat increased tissue blood perfusion, enhancing the absorption of subcutaneously applied insulin, and demonstrated significant effects on insulin absorption and postprandial glucose excursions in clinical trials.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely individuals with diabetes requiring insulin therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of acupuncture compared to other treatments, including massage, for facial spasm.
results_summary: The study found that acupuncture was reported as superior to massage and other treatments for facial spasm, but the methodological quality of the included studies was poor, limiting definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: 1262 participants with facial spasm, all studies conducted in China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review established, new, and alternative emergency medicine techniques, including external cardiac massage, for airway management, drug administration, and hemorrhagic shock management.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about massage's effects, focusing instead on broader emergency medicine techniques and their forensic evaluation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general emergency medicine context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent findings on the pathophysiology and management of pain in MS patients, including the role of non-pharmacological treatments like massage therapy.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that non-pharmacological procedures such as massage therapy have been used in the treatment of MS patients, but it does not provide specific efficacy data or outcomes related to massage. The focus is on the broader context of pain management in MS.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) experiencing painful conditions such as neuropathy, migraines, and neuralgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of sweet potato/footbath/acupressure massage (SFA) intervention in preventing constipation and improving bowel emptying satisfaction in hospitalized patients with acute coronary syndromes (ACS).
results_summary: The SFA intervention significantly reduced constipation incidence, decreased laxative/enema use, improved patient satisfaction with bowel emptying, and alleviated sensations of incomplete evacuation and anorectal obstruction compared to usual care alone.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with acute coronary syndromes (ACS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of total glucosides of paeony capsule (TGPC) combined with massage in treating mild and moderate alopecia areata.
results_summary: The study found that TGPC combined with massage showed similar efficacy and safety profiles to compound glycyrrhizin tablets, with both treatments improving T-cell subsets and reducing the Th/Ts ratio. The cured and markedly effective rates increased over the three-month period, with no significant difference between the groups.
population_specificity: 86 outpatients with mild and moderate alopecia areata.
effective_dosage: Massage was applied to bold patches, but specific details on frequency or technique were not provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tactile/kinesthetic stimulation (TKS), a form of infant massage, could improve bone strength and markers of bone accretion in preterm infants.
results_summary: TKS attenuated the decrease in tibial speed of sound (a surrogate for bone strength) observed in control infants and led to greater increases in urinary osteocalcin, suggesting improved bone metabolism and mineralization.
population_specificity: Preterm, appropriate-for-gestational-age (AGA) infants (29-32 weeks post-menstrual age).
effective_dosage: Twice daily TKS, 6 days per week.

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of soft tissue massage, either alone or combined with exercise, for treating non-specific shoulder problems.
results_summary: Low-quality evidence suggests soft tissue massage moderately improves active flexion, abduction range of motion, pain, and functional scores compared to no treatment, but only immediately post-treatment. Exercise showed small pain improvements but no significant functional or range-of-motion benefits.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-80 with non-surgical painful shoulder disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of massage as a treatment for anejaculatory dysfunction in spinal cord injured (SCI) patients.
results_summary: The study found that massage, along with vibrators, electrical stimulation, and surgical biopsy, can be used to obtain sperm for intra-uterine or in-vitro fertilization in SCI patients with anejaculatory dysfunction.
population_specificity: Male spinal cord injured (SCI) patients with anejaculatory dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of massage therapy as a treatment for infantile colic.
results_summary: The study found that massage therapy, along with other alternative treatments, has not proven to be consistently helpful for infantile colic, and some methods might even be dangerous.
population_specificity: Infants aged 2 weeks to 4 months with infantile colic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether spontaneous pushing alone or combined with perineal massage reduces the incidence of postpartum urinary incontinence compared to traditional directed pushing.
results_summary: The study found no statistical difference in the incidence of postpartum incontinence between spontaneous pushing, perineal massage, or their combination compared to traditional directed pushing. High crossover between randomization groups may have influenced the results.
population_specificity: Primiparous women (first-time mothers) in the postpartum period.
effective_dosage: Not specified (perineal massage initiated in the third trimester).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but follow-up was at 12 months postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the rate of nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO) resolution in infants aged 6 to less than 10 months with nonsurgical management involving nasolacrimal duct massage and topical antibiotics.
results_summary: The study found that 66% of eyes with NLDO resolved without surgery after 6 months of nonsurgical management (massage and topical antibiotics as needed). None of the baseline characteristics (age, sex, laterality, prior treatment) were associated with resolution.
population_specificity: Infants aged 6 to less than 10 months with NLDO and no history of nasolacrimal duct surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (massage and topical antibiotics as needed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the biological effects of repeated Swedish massage versus light touch on hormonal and immune markers in healthy young adults.
results_summary: Weekly Swedish massage increased lymphocyte markers and decreased cytokine production, while twice-weekly massage increased oxytocin, decreased vasopressin and cortisol, and slightly increased pro-inflammatory cytokines. The effects varied by session frequency.
population_specificity: Medically and psychiatrically healthy young adults.
effective_dosage: 45 minutes of Swedish massage or light touch, either weekly or twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critique physio-therapeutic approaches to therapeutic touch, examining its historical role in defining physiotherapy's professional identity and how current practices may constrain new therapeutic possibilities.
results_summary: The study found that physiotherapy's disciplinary approach to therapeutic touch, established in the 1890s, persists today and may limit the profession's ability to adapt to modern healthcare demands. It also highlighted the profession's historical management of touch's innate sensuality and the technologies that shaped its identity.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on historical and professional critique rather than a specific patient population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of ice massage, acupressure, and placebo in reducing labor pain intensity in pregnant women.
results_summary: Ice massage and acupressure significantly reduced labor pain, with ice massage providing more persistent relief. The difference in pain reduction was statistically significant at 30 minutes post-intervention.
population_specificity: 90 pregnant women (mean age 27.82 ± 6.20 years) from selected hospitals in Tehran, Iran.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention applied at the Hegu point).
study_duration: Pain assessed before, immediately, 30 minutes, and 1 hour after intervention.

study_goal: The researchers reviewed the role and limitations of diagnostic tests, including carotid sinus massage, in evaluating syncope.
results_summary: The abstract mentions the interpretation of carotid sinus massage results but does not provide specific findings on its efficacy or safety. Reflex syncope was identified as the most common etiology in the general population, with cardiac syncope having a worse prognosis.
population_specificity: General population, with specific reference to patients with syncope and bundle branch block.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of therapeutic massage (TM) and deep tissue massage (DTM) in treating chronic low back pain in elderly patients.
results_summary: Both TM and DTM showed statistically significant improvements in pain and disability measures (ODI, QBPD, VAS). DTM was significantly more effective than TM in reducing disability (ODI) and pain (VAS).
population_specificity: 26 patients aged 60-75 years with chronic low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the types of CAM most studied in children, the conditions they address, and the methodologies used, with massage being one of the modalities reviewed.
results_summary: The abstract notes that massage was among the most common CAM modalities studied in children, but it does not provide specific findings on its effects. The majority of articles were reviews or non-hypothesis-driven, though some randomized controlled trials and systematic reviews were identified.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of manual therapy, including massage, as an adjunctive management approach for COPD.
results_summary: The study found limited evidence for massage in COPD management, with only 5 subjects receiving massage and no significant physiological improvements reported. Patient-reported measures showed some improvement in subjective outcomes like 'improved health' and 'breathing difficulty,' but the overall evidence was weak.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: To update evidence-based clinical practice guidelines on the use of massage compared to controls or other treatments for adults with sub-acute and chronic neck pain.
results_summary: Therapeutic massage was found to decrease pain, tenderness, and improve range of motion for sub-acute and chronic neck pain, with 8 positive recommendations (6 grade A and 2 grade C+). However, data was insufficient for long-term effects.
population_specificity: Adults (>18 years) suffering from sub-acute and chronic neck pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of spiritual and religious interventions, including meditation combined with massage, on well-being and quality of life in terminally ill adults.
results_summary: The study found that meditation combined with massage buffered against a reduction in quality of life in the medium term, but no significant differences were observed in well-being or quality of life between intervention and control groups overall.
population_specificity: Adults in the terminal phase of a disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of therapeutic massage on improving range of motion and reducing pain in patients with neck pain, comparing it to standard rehabilitation methods.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant pain reduction and improved function, but the massage group demonstrated statistically significant improvements in specific ranges of motion (flexion and lateral bends). The effectiveness of massage was comparable to standard rehabilitation alone.
population_specificity: 60 patients aged 37-82 years (mean age: 62.8) with neck pain, treated at a rehabilitation department.

study_goal: To investigate the acute effects of traditional Thai massage (TTM) on brain electrical activity, anxiety, and pain in patients with scapulocostal syndrome (SCS).
results_summary: TTM significantly reduced anxiety and pain intensity more than physical therapy (PT) and increased relaxation as shown by EEG changes (increased delta activity, decreased theta, alpha, and beta activity). PT also reduced anxiety and pain but to a lesser extent.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with scapulocostal syndrome (SCS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of the Back School program (active therapy, ergonomics, and education) against passive physiotherapy (including massage) in reducing pain intensity and improving body posture in nurses with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that both the Back School group and the passive physiotherapy group (which included massage) showed significant reductions in pain intensity, but the Back School group demonstrated better long-term results at six-month and one-year follow-ups. Passive therapies like massage showed initial benefits but were less effective in sustained pain reduction and posture improvement compared to the Back School program.
population_specificity: 124 nurses with chronic low back pain at the University of Pecs, Faculty of Health Sciences.
effective_dosage: Passive physiotherapy (including massage) was administered once a week for six weeks.
study_duration: Six weeks of intervention, with follow-ups at six and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of massage as part of lower limb physical therapy for children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found limited evidence for massage's effectiveness, with interventions targeting body function and structure level showing influence primarily at that level without significant impact on activity level.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of massage, among other integrative therapies, in addressing wound pain and improving quality of life for patients with chronic wounds.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that massage, along with other integrative therapies, may help address wound pain and improve well-being, though research on its specific role in wound care is limited.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic wounds, incontinence-related skin damage, or peristomal complications, including palliative care patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of dual parent- and trainer-delivered qigong massage on motor skills and sensory responses in young children with developmental delay and motor tone abnormalities.
results_summary: The study found large effect-size improvements in motor skills (Peabody Gross Motor Scale scores) in children with cerebral palsy and Down syndrome after 5 months of intervention, with continued improvement at 10-month follow-up. Sensory responses showed no significant treatment effect.
population_specificity: 28 children under age 4 with developmental delay and motor tone abnormalities (14 with cerebral palsy and high motor tone, 14 with Down syndrome and low motor tone).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of aromatherapy massage on menopausal symptoms.
results_summary: Both aromatherapy massage and placebo massage significantly reduced menopausal symptoms compared to the control group, with aromatherapy massage showing greater efficacy than placebo massage.
population_specificity: 90 women attending a menopausal clinic at a gynecology hospital in Tehran.
effective_dosage: 30-minute aromatherapy massage sessions twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of massage combined with exercise on pain and mood in patients with advanced terminal cancer.
results_summary: The study found that massage and exercises significantly reduced worst pain, current pain, and psychological distress in terminal cancer patients compared to a sham treatment, though no significant differences were observed for physical distress or least pain.
population_specificity: Patients with terminal cancer (24 participants).
effective_dosage: Six sessions of 30-35 minutes over 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether parotid gland massage could reduce radioisotope accumulation in the salivary gland, potentially preventing salivary damage from (131)I therapy.
results_summary: The study found that parotid gland massage significantly reduced Tc-99m pertechnetate accumulation compared to no massage, with a higher percentage of patients showing negative accumulation ratios in the massage group.
population_specificity: 60 patients with differentiated thyroid cancer undergoing (131)I therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (massage performed between two salivary gland scans).
study_duration: Not specified (intervention occurred between two scans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if carbetocin (an oxytocin agonist) reduces the need for uterine massage compared to conventional uterotonic agents (oxytocin and syntometrine) in preventing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
results_summary: Carbetocin significantly reduced the need for uterine massage after both caesarean and vaginal deliveries compared to oxytocin. It also showed lower blood loss and fewer adverse effects (e.g., nausea, vomiting) compared to syntometrine.
population_specificity: Postpartum women, including those undergoing caesarean or vaginal deliveries, with and without risk factors for PPH.
effective_dosage: 100 µg intravenous carbetocin; oxytocin dosages varied.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of abdominal massage on high gastric residual volume, abdominal distension, and vomiting in patients receiving intermittent enteral nutrition via nasogastric tube.
results_summary: The study found that abdominal massage significantly reduced high gastric residual volume (2.5% vs. 30% in controls), abdominal distension (2.5% vs. 20%), and vomiting (0% vs. 10%) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients intermittently fed with enteral nutrition through a nasogastric tube in a university hospital setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of pelvic floor myofascial physical therapy versus global therapeutic massage in women with newly symptomatic interstitial cystitis/painful bladder syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that myofascial physical therapy had a significantly higher response rate (59%) compared to global therapeutic massage (26%). Both treatments reduced pain, urgency, and frequency, but there was no significant difference in these secondary outcomes between the groups.
population_specificity: Women with interstitial cystitis/painful bladder syndrome and demonstrable pelvic floor tenderness, with symptom duration of no more than 3 years.
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated, but involved 10 treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether Chinese manipulation improves pain, function/disability, and global perceived effect in adults with acute/subacute/chronic neck pain.
results_summary: The study found very low-quality evidence suggesting Chinese manipulation provided more immediate post-intervention pain relief and improvement of global signs and symptoms compared to cervical traction or traditional massage, though the evidence was limited.
population_specificity: Adults with acute, subacute, or chronic neck pain.
study_duration: Immediate post-intervention effects were measured; duration of intervention not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the accuracy and readability of online information regarding the treatment and management of acute low back pain (ALBP), including the effectiveness of massage.
results_summary: The study found that information about massage was among the lowest scoring categories for accuracy (9%), indicating poor reliability of online resources. The most accurately reported category was "Education and reassurance" (98%), while massage and other treatments lacked evidence-based content.
population_specificity: General public seeking online health information about ALBP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of drugs acting on the melatonin system as future treatment options for treatment-resistant depression (TRD).
results_summary: The abstract mentions melatonin as a promising future option for TRD but does not provide specific findings on its effects.
population_specificity: Patients with treatment-resistant depression (TRD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exogenous melatonin acts as a sleep promoter and antidepressant in individuals with major depressive disorder (MDD) and early-morning waking.
results_summary: The study found general improvements in depression and sleep over time, but these were not specific to melatonin. However, there was a trend toward mood improvement with melatonin, and no adverse side effects were observed.
population_specificity: 33 participants with MDD and early-morning waking (31 completed the trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Melatonin for treating REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD).
results_summary: Melatonin was suggested for RBD treatment with few side effects, though its efficacy was not as strongly supported as other treatments like Clonazepam. The abstract notes its advantage of minimal adverse effects compared to other pharmacologic options.
population_specificity: Patients with REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD), particularly those needing pharmacologic therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review melatonin's neuroprotective properties in neurodegenerative diseases, focusing on its effects on pathogenic proteins, mitochondrial function, and cellular viability.
results_summary: Melatonin was identified as having multiple neuroprotective mechanisms, warranting further study for neuroprotection in neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. The abstract highlights its potential but notes limitations in current data.
population_specificity: Preclinical in vitro, ex vivo, and nonhuman in vivo studies (not specified for melatonin alone).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate melatonin's effectiveness in treating circadian rhythm sleep disorders and insomnia, as well as explore the potential of selective melatonin receptor agonists.
results_summary: Melatonin is effective for circadian rhythm sleep disorders (e.g., advanced/delayed sleep phase, jet lag, shift work) but less compelling for primary insomnia. Melatonin receptor agonists (ramelteon, tasimelteon, agomelatine) show promise but require further mechanistic studies.
population_specificity: Individuals with circadian rhythm sleep disorders and some types of insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effectiveness of various treatments, including Melatonin, for Primary Stabbing Headache (PSH) based on a systematic analysis of literature from 1980-2009.
results_summary: The study found that Melatonin may be effective in treating PSH, alongside other treatments like COX-2 inhibitors, gabapentin, nifedipine, and paracetamol, though indomethacin remains the primary option.
population_specificity: Patients with Primary Stabbing Headache (PSH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to detect melatonin in gingival crevicular fluid (GCF) and assess its levels in saliva and GCF across different stages of periodontal disease, while also examining the correlation between salivary and GCF melatonin.
results_summary: Melatonin was detected in GCF at lower concentrations than in saliva, with the lowest levels found in chronic periodontitis patients. Both salivary and GCF melatonin levels decreased with disease severity, suggesting a potential protective role against periodontal disease.
population_specificity: 45 subjects divided into healthy individuals, gingivitis patients, and periodontitis patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of preoperative oral melatonin on sedation, sleep quality, and postoperative analgesia in patients undergoing elective prostatectomy.
results_summary: Melatonin significantly reduced intraoperative fentanyl usage, pain scores, and tramadol consumption while improving postoperative sleep quality and sedation scores compared to the placebo. However, it prolonged extubation and recovery times.
population_specificity: ASA I-II patients undergoing elective prostatectomy (n=52).
effective_dosage: 6 mg melatonin the night before and 1 hour before surgery.
study_duration: Administered the night before and 1 hour before surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of exogenous melatonin in treating GERD, either alone or in combination with omeprazole.
results_summary: Melatonin improved GERD symptoms when used alone or with omeprazole, though omeprazole alone was more effective. Melatonin effectively relieved epigastric pain and heartburn.
population_specificity: 36 persons divided into 4 groups (control, melatonin alone, omeprazole alone, combination therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of various interventions, including melatonin, for aborting or preventing cluster headaches.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding melatonin's effects, only mentioning it as one of the interventions reviewed.
population_specificity: Patients with cluster headaches (based on IHS criteria).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review analytical techniques for quantifying melatonin and other biomarkers in biological samples.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific findings about melatonin's effects, only its inclusion as an analyte in the reviewed methodologies.
population_specificity: Not specified (general biological samples, including urine, plasma, serum, and tissues).

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of melatonin for treating insomnia in pediatric patients with ADHD.
results_summary: Melatonin improved sleep onset and latency in children with ADHD and insomnia, with transient and mild adverse events. However, studies were limited by small size, short duration, and variable criteria.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (6-14 years old) with ADHD and insomnia.
effective_dosage: 3 to 6 mg administered within a few hours of bedtime.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current treatment options for Circadian Rhythm Sleep Disorders, including the administration of exogenous melatonin.
results_summary: The abstract mentions melatonin as a treatment option but does not provide specific results on its effectiveness. It highlights the broader context of sleep disorders and current diagnostic methods.
population_specificity: Individuals with Circadian Rhythm Sleep Disorders (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exogenous melatonin (5mg) could reduce depressive symptoms in patients with Delayed Sleep Phase Syndrome (DSPS).
results_summary: Melatonin significantly reduced depression scores in depressed DSPS patients and improved sleep continuity in both depressed and non-depressed groups. Group I (depressed patients) showed marked alterations in melatonin rhythms compared to Group II.
population_specificity: Patients with Delayed Sleep Phase Syndrome (DSPS), divided into those with (n=8) and without (n=12) depressive symptoms.
study_duration: 4 weeks per treatment (melatonin and placebo), with a 1-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of melatonin in the synchronization of Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium chabaudi life cycles and explore its potential therapeutic applications in malaria treatment.
results_summary: Melatonin stimulates Plasmodium falciparum growth via receptor activation and Ca2+ signaling, promoting parasite maturation. High-dose melatonin reduces oxidative stress and liver damage, while melatonin antagonists disrupt parasite synchronization, suggesting a dual therapeutic approach.
population_specificity: In vitro studies and rodent models (Plasmodium chabaudi); implications for human malaria (Plasmodium falciparum).
effective_dosage: High doses (specific amounts not stated) and melatonin antagonist luzindole used.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of exogenous melatonin on sleep quality and inflammation/oxidative stress markers in cystic fibrosis (CF) patients.
results_summary: Melatonin improved sleep efficiency and reduced nitrite levels in exhaled breath condensate, but did not significantly affect isoprostane levels. The study suggests melatonin may benefit sleep and certain oxidative stress markers in CF patients.
population_specificity: Clinically stable cystic fibrosis patients without recent infectious exacerbation or hospitalization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of norepinephrine (NE) in the actions of wake- and sleep-promoting drugs, including Melatonin, within the framework of brain arousal systems.
results_summary: The study found that Melatonin increases sleep by suppressing the activity of neurons in the brain's circadian clock, and NE influences the synthesis of Melatonin.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of pharmacological mechanisms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically review the effects of melatonin supplementation on sports performance and health biomarkers in highly trained athletes.
results_summary: Melatonin supplementation improved antioxidant status, inflammatory response, and reversed liver and muscle damage. Moderate effects were observed on glycemia, cholesterol, triglycerides, and creatinine, with promising but inconclusive data on hematological biomarkers, hormonal responses, and sports performance.
population_specificity: Highly trained athletes
effective_dosage: 5 mg to 100 mg, administered before or after exercise

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential therapeutic benefits of melatonin in treating various oral cavity diseases, focusing on its antioxidant, immunomodulatory, and tissue-protective properties.
results_summary: Melatonin may protect the oral cavity from oxidative stress-related damage and shows potential benefits in treating periodontal diseases, viral infections, Candida, xerostomia, oral ulcers, and oral cancer, though more specific studies are needed.
population_specificity: General oral cavity disease conditions (not specific to a demographic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of melatonin in counteracting the pro-ageing effects of toxic aldehydes by supporting lipid-radical cycles and the glyoxalase system.
results_summary: The study suggests melatonin, along with lipid-radical cycles and the glyoxalase system, has an anti-ageing effect by opposing the negative actions of toxic aldehydes like MDA and MG, which contribute to metabolic disorders and age-related diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (general ageing process discussed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of 5-HTP supplementation on sleep quality and gut microbiota composition in older adults.
results_summary: 5-HTP supplementation improved certain sleep quality components, particularly in poor sleepers, and increased serum serotonin levels. It also positively influenced gut microbiota composition in poor sleepers.
population_specificity: Older adults (66 ± 3 years) in Singapore.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine melatonin's role in circadian rhythm regulation and its potential as a chronotherapeutic agent for age-related disorders.
results_summary: The study found that melatonin synchronizes circadian rhythms, regulates redox homeostasis during aging, and may protect against age-dependent circadian rhythm disruption. Exogenous melatonin supplementation shows promise as an effective chronotherapeutic medicine.
population_specificity: Older individuals experiencing circadian rhythm disruption and aging-related decline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate melatonin's role in protecting against oxidative stress and improving pregnancy outcomes by mitigating common disorders like preeclampsia, fetal growth retardation, and premature delivery.
results_summary: Melatonin was found to reduce oxidative stress and improve pregnancy outcomes by protecting the placenta and fetus, as well as synchronizing circadian rhythms disrupted during pregnancy. Experimental supplementation showed reduced frequency and severity of pregnancy-related disorders.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals and fetal development.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of melatonin supplementation on physical performance, recovery, and whether exercise alters melatonin secretion in athletes and exercise practitioners.
results_summary: Melatonin supplementation did not improve aerobic performance but enhanced post-exercise recovery without altering melatonin secretion.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects, athletes, and exercise practitioners.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining intradialytic concurrent training with melatonin supplementation improves functional capacity, muscle strength, postural balance, and quality of life in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Melatonin combined with exercise improved postural balance in dual-task conditions and some quality-of-life domains more than exercise alone, while both exercise groups showed benefits in functional capacity, muscle strength, and postural balance.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether melatonin plays a role in clearing pathological molecules from the brain via the glymphatic system and its potential benefits in neurological health, particularly in Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study found that melatonin enhances clearance of amyloid-β peptide (Aβ) from the CNS, defers Aβ accumulation in animal models, and reduces neurobehavioral signs like sundowning in Alzheimer's patients. It also maintains circadian rhythmicity and supports neural stem cell activity.
population_specificity: Animal models of Alzheimer's disease and preliminary data from Alzheimer's patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of melatonin supplementation during a high-sodium diet on 24-hour blood pressure and blood pressure reactivity during sympathetic activation tests.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study focused on melatonin's role in blood pressure regulation under high-sodium conditions and during sympathetic activation tests like isometric handgrip exercise, postexercise ischemia, and the cold pressor test.
population_specificity: 22 participants (11 men, 11 women), aged 26.5 ± 3.1 years, BMI 24.1 ± 1.8 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety profile of long-term melatonin use by analyzing adverse event data from prospective trials.
results_summary: The study found that the reported frequency of adverse events associated with long-term melatonin use is low, with few clinically significant events, but noted a scarcity of high-quality data from double-blind randomized placebo-controlled trials.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with extended melatonin use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate endothelial damage and vascular stiffness in hypertensive patients and test the effect of melatonin supplementation on these parameters.
results_summary: The study found that arterial stiffness improved significantly in hypertensive patients supplemented with melatonin, though other specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients of either gender (n=23).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore melatonin's role in modulating obesity-associated inflammation, metabolic homeostasis, and immune response regulation.
results_summary: Melatonin supplementation was found to reduce body weight, improve metabolic profiles, and ameliorate immune responses and pro-inflammatory stimuli. It also modulates oxidative stress, adipokine secretion, and promotes a white-to-brown adipose tissue switch.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and associated complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent chromatographic methods used for detecting melatonin over the last three decades, focusing on gas chromatography and high-performance liquid chromatography.
results_summary: The study reviewed various analytical methods for melatonin detection but did not report specific findings on its effects or outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (methodological review, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review melatonin's physiological roles, safety, and efficacy in treating sleep disorders, particularly insomnia.
results_summary: Melatonin modestly advances sleep onset but has variable effects; it impacts multiple physiological systems and has clinically important drug interactions. In children with neurodevelopmental disabilities, it improves sleep onset but not sleep efficiency.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects and children with neurodevelopmental disabilities.
interactions: Clinically important drug interactions mentioned, but specifics not provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of melatonin with other hypnotics on sleep outcomes in adults and older adults, both short-term and long-term.
results_summary: Melatonin had little effect on adults but showed some efficacy in the elderly. It was less effective compared to other hypnotics like ORAs and H1-antagonists.
population_specificity: Adults and older adults with primary insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine melatonin's antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and biological functions in relation to physical exercise, focusing on its secretion and effects on exercise-induced oxidative stress in athletes.
results_summary: Melatonin supplementation strengthens antioxidant status in trained athletes, reducing oxidative stress and inflammation markers during intense exercise. Intense exercise disturbs antioxidant status, but melatonin counteracts these effects effectively.
population_specificity: Competitive and trained athletes in various sports.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of exogenous melatonin on circadian misalignment and body weight among overweight night shift workers, considering chronotype differences.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent effects of melatonin on body weight in human shift workers, though it had shown positive results in animal models. The impact varied by chronotype, with early types potentially experiencing greater circadian misalignment.
population_specificity: 27 female nurses (average age 37.1, BMI 29.9 kg/m²) working night shifts.
effective_dosage: 3 mg administered on non-night shift nights.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether melatonin supplementation could mitigate the negative effects of sleep deprivation on psychomotor performance and physical fitness measures in collegiate student-athletes.
results_summary: Melatonin improved static and dynamic balance, anaerobic power, blood lactate levels, and reaction time compared to placebo under both 4-hour and 24-hour sleep deprivation conditions. The placebo group showed negative effects from sleep deprivation, with more severe impacts after 24 hours.
population_specificity: Ten trained male collegiate student-athletes (mean age 20 ± 2 years).
effective_dosage: 6 mg administered orally 30 minutes before testing.
study_duration: Single-dose intervention per session, with six sessions spaced 72 hours apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether melatonin supplementation improves arterial stiffness, mitochondrial DNA copy number, and insulin resistance in older women with insomnia.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that melatonin improved cardiometabolic parameters like arterial stiffness, mtDNA, or insulin resistance, but sleep quality was improved in the melatonin group.
population_specificity: Healthy women aged 55 years and older with untreated insomnia (PSQI ≥ 5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the precise relationship between melatonin supplementation and oxidative stress by analyzing randomized controlled trials.
